Brings back alot of cool memories. Had to complete annual Altitude training at the Alt. Chamber at Fairchild  AFB. It wasn't until several years after I retired from the Air Force and flying for a major airline that this valuable training was a life saver. Airline pilots typically never get the privilege to go a barometric chamber unless they flew in the military.  At 39,000 ft I had an explosive decompression when a cabin window seal failed and blew out. Luckily there were no pax or cabin crew in the back as we were ferrying the a/c from maintenance. Believe me it was scary the cockpit filled with fog and a very loud pop plus it was at night. We didnt know what had happened until after we landed.

It’s technically not lack of oxygen, but lack of pressure. Your lungs work on partial pressure. So when you increase in altitude the pressure decreases, so you’ll have oxygen, but there isn’t enough pressure for it to diffuse through the lung and into the blood stream.

Don't assume this would be a happy death everyone! Some people get happy but others have very different symptoms!
Some get angry, some get anxious, some seem to have no symptoms except maybe reduced judgement. Look up Helios Flight 522, where a plane slowly decompressed without anyone realizing. The pilots on that flight didn't get happy, one got very anxious and obsessed with fixing a warning light that he should have known was meaningless, and the other got quite quiet and sleepy. They both then fell unconscious and the plane eventually crashed despite the best efforts of a flight attendant who had an oxygen tank but no key code to the cockpit door.
Meanwhile on Japan Air 123 the pilots experienced seemingly almost no effects until the plane crashed and made incredible efforts to save the plane despite possible hypoxia! it's a terrifyingly unpredictable thing and you don't want to risk it. Wear your mask immediately!

I did this in med school. Crazy experience! I had to count backwards in steps of 3 and write every number down, so from 1000 to 997 to 994 and so on, so that the people around me could see how well my brain still worked. In thermo we learned about Fermi–Dirac statistics. Air particle density follows a Fermi–Dirac distribution. This determines the density at different altitudes. The Fermi–Dirac distribution tells us about the relative probabilities of particles occupying different energy levels. As the number of particles increases, the mathematical representation becomes more accurate. In a pressure cabin, such as an airplane or test chamber, the number of particles is very large, so Fermi–Dirac statistics are reliably accurate. I believe this is accurate. Good video, although he didn’t really go deep into the physics behind it. A lot of people think altitude based hypoxia is caused by a lack of oxygen at higher altitudes. That is just a small part of it. Even if you are breathing 100% oxygen it’s not enough at around 35000 to 37000 ft. The reason hypoxia occurs at altitude is because the transfer of oxygen to the hemoglobin in your blood occurs due to pressure differences. In your lungs, the partial pressure of water vapour and co2 is almost constant at all altitudes, so when the total pressure drops, the partial pressure of oxygen (and nitrogen) drops. When the partial pressure of oxygen drops too low, no oxygen transfer can happen, and the hemoglobin does not pick up new oxygen molecules, no matter how many oxygen molecules that are floating around in your lungs. That’s why oxygen masks for pilots are delivered with automatic over pressure that forces the air into your lungs, depending on cabin altitude. For passengers, however, it is expected that they put on their masks, and maybe pass out on the way down, but the aircraft will descend below 35000 feet quickly if the pilots does their job, and the passengers will quicken rather quickly once getting lower. Also, most airliners can fly above 40000 feet. At those altitudes you have about 3 to 7 seconds of useful consciousness if you get a rapid or instant decompression, which again, is why it is crucial to get on your oxygen mask quickly. As you saw in the short clip he showed, you will get mist forming as the air pressure decreases and can no longer hold the moisture. You will have around 1 second of blindness due to the mist and a couple of seconds of confusion, so not a lot of time to get the mask on before you pass out.

I put people to sleep using inhalation anesthesia.
It is amazing to see how fast it knocks people out if you saturate the lungs with the anestheetic mixture completely with full tidal volume technique.
The route from pulmonary veins to the brains is just a couple of seconds.
Same goes for hypoxia. If you remove oxygen from pulmonary alveoles, it gets out of the blood as well. Gasping low-oxygen air only empties your body's reserves faster. Also CO-2 goes down and hemoglobin sticks to the remaining oxygen harder, not giving it out.
A few seconds and the brain goes off. It happens sneakily and fast.

I recently got the chance to fly in a Hypo chamber for class at UND. It was insane to watch other people in my class (all future airline/professional pilots) go through hypoxia and compare the breadth of symptoms. Some got confused and anxious, others lost coordination. I get air hunger immediately, that stabilized after a few seconds, then joints start aching, and I lose coordination. It's funny how that differs so greatly.

This is the exact methodology behind the "exit bag" which people use to self-terminate - the only difference being said people breathe in an inert gas to facilitate hypoxia. The physiology behind the "exit bag" is pretty simple: inspiring an inert gas such as helium or nitrogen displaces oxygen and prevents it entering circulation, thus inducing hypoxia. During said time the person will experience no respiratory distress (or the struggling that is associated with suffocation) because there is no residual build up of CO2, which in turn means the body's chemoreceptors do not induce changes in ventilation to offset the hypoxia. Dying, either intentionally or accidentally, via the inspiration of an inert gas and hypoxia is completely pain free and peaceful. Without an adequate supply of oxygen, the brain "shuts off" and the person loses consciousness within seconds followed by a swift death within few minutes.

Is it that when you hold your breath there is relatively oxygen rich air in your lungs that you keep on using, but when you are in a depressurized cabin, the high pressure air escapes your lungs and you are left with thinner air that you keep on breathing. Breathing helps to get more oxygen into your brain, but not quickly enough to compensate the oxygen you are using. So that is why you can experience hypoxia more quickly at high altitude while breathing vs at sea level by holding your breath.

It's important to realize that breathing oxygen prior bought Destin a lot of time as well. He mentions that at FL250 he had more time than an airline passenger would at FL350, but also because he was breathing oxygen prior. Excess oxygen becomes dissolved into the blood stream, even after hemoglobin is fully saturated (that was the "PulseOx" number on his finger, how saturated his hemoglobin was with oxygen). Also his lungs became full of nearly 100% oxygen instead of the normal 21% oxygen, so even though he continued to respire there is a functional reserve in the lung that does not get exchanged with every breath, and oxygen can continue to be transported into the blood stream at higher levels. In medicine we use these concepts in emergency situations. The benefit of pre-oxygenation is even more pronounced when respiration is temporarily stopped for procedures like endotracheal intubation.

This is a good video for all pilots to watch. I fly pressurized. The FAA offers FREE Hypoxic Training and they bring the center near you (within the USA). They brought us up to 28,500. I lasted for around 4:30. A buddy went past 5 minutes and he wanted to stay off of air and the FAA guys gave him no choice. What I did notice... was while I was hypoxic, one single breath if O2 brought me right back to 100%, it was that fast. Vision to the feeling of control. Now when I fly, I always have a portable small bottle of O2 within reach. You have to identify it fast in order to get down below 12,500. Quickly... or, get an air supply.. this of your passengers... they simply have no clue or idea how this will hit them..

On the other hand, under normal circumstances if a cabin depressurisation occurs the pilots will conduct an emergency descent in such a rapid fashion you would not be hypoxic for long enough to sustain any brain damage, even if you go unconscious. It's not good, but in most conditions it's mostly a nuisance (you might sustain side effects like nausea and the like) rather than any actual danger. With that said, conditions could occur where an emergency descent isn't immediately possible, for example traffic below, the need to retain altitude due to a lack of power, etc, and if you (and your kids!) doesn't have your masks on when you pass out then, you may be in some real trouble.

On April 1, 2011, Southwest Airlines Flight 812 had a rapid depressurization "event" when a flap of the fuselage skin peeled back. There were only two injuries (both minor) with one of them being a flight attendant who attempted to make an interphone call to the flight deck before putting on his oxygen mask. He passed out before completing the call, pitched forward, and broke his nose when he faceplanted into some part of the aircraft cabin. That's how little time you have at cruising altitude to get your mask on.

Earlier this year, NASA reported that something in space has been messing with its astronauts' perfect eyesight, causing long-term impairment to their quality of vision. Astronaut Scott Kelly, whose exceptional vision was part of the reason he was selected to be America's first astronaut to spend a full year in space, says he's been forced to wear reading glasses since coming home. John Phillips, who spent time on the International Space Station (ISS) in 2005, brought his sudden bouts of blurry vision home with him, and during his post-flight physical, NASA confirmed that his vision had gone from 20/20 to 20/100 in just six months. NASA suspected that the condition - called visual impairment inter cranial pressure syndrome, or VIIP - was caused by the lack of gravity in space. 
Science Alert, Space Could Leave You Blind, And Scientists Say They've Finally Figured Out Why, 2016

Most astronauts feel dizziness and nausea in the first few days in space but blurred vision seems to be more lasting.

Watch some of the inflight videos of passengers putting on their masks durning a de-pressurization  event. Just about everyone will put the mask on and not cover their nose. Then next time you are on the airplane WATCH the safety video and READ the safety card and see and hear the command "Put the mask over your nose and mouth". The reason we do a very fast decent, is most will not follow instructions during a scary event and getting to a lower altitude fast will keep most everyone who does it wrong or does not get a mask on alive. You most likely will have to see the actual scary event on a vertical video someone shot on their phone. Most also have no idea how to shoot video.

You would not die, you would black out. If someone puts the mask on you at this stage, you would breathe unconsciously and recover within a few breaths. This brings back some old memories...  When I went to the US Army helicopter flight school at Ft. Rucker, we did this training as well.  And I was the guy that had the shape toy, though it was the original ball one.  I'm from Colorado (elevation 5800') so I was the last to have to get back on O2.  Like you, I made it through the shapes about 1 1/2 times and then tried to put the square in the circular hole for about 15 seconds. That's when they put my mask on for me.  We also had a large poster color chart - kind of like the old TV test screen. It was interesting to see how the colors faded and tunnel vision occurred.  Thanks for your videos... very entertaining and enlightening, too.

I have gotten Hypoxia many  times from sleep apnea. under sleep study my O2 was in the low 60s for 2 hours.  and even into the the high 50s for a minute here and there throughout the study. I wake up confused clumsy angry and belligerent.  shakes rapid heart rate. borderline stroking or aneurysm from high blood pressure.  sleep apnea sucks.  this guy only wnet seconds  but go for hours with O2 stats in the 60s and it takes you all day to recover. it is debilitating and disabling.   I might add that my sleep apnea is Central apnea. or Central nervous system related. My brain stops telling my diaphragm to move and I literally stop breathing and dont gasp for air until fight or flight kicks in. this goes on for hours every time i sleep.  i had 240 breathing interruptions in 2.5 hours. averaging 90 breathing interruptions and hour.  this means i literally stop breathing more than once every minute. going for as much as 40 seconds before struggling for a breath.  it is exhausting and effects every aspect of your life. most people don't even know they are suffering but they do Not have it nearly as bad as i do.  Drs believe my Central sleep apnea is related to a head trauma I sustained and further brain damage has occurred while sleeping / not breathing. some Stroke victims suffer from central sleep apnea.  others would be quadriplegics or neck injuries who have lost neurological impulses to the diaphragm and are on a ventilator.   if you wake up gasping for air or see someone stop breathing when they sleep get help. have a sleep study done.

Important addition to Hypoxia in aviation:
Another thing to add, some aircraft at or above 40,000 MSL including A380 require pressurized O2 to alleviate harmful effects of hypoxia.
Airlines tend to always provide pilots with O2 masks that deliver pressurized O2. You may still feel the effects of hypoxia for a moment as a passenger since those masks only deliver 100% non-pressurized O2.
So always fix your mask first, then help others. And you may still suffer some effects of hypoxia if at altitude that would require pressurized O2.

The concept is that the pilot will immediately descend to altitude that doesn't need pressurized O2 (below 40,000 MSL), and eventually below 14,000/12,000 MSL where supplemental O2 shouldn't be required by the general population.

Another big point: hypoxia at altitude is not the same as holding your breath.

The reduced pressure causes all gasses to expand, which includes O2 in your blood and organs to come out of solution faster than usual; like opening a fizzy drink; except that's O2 fizzing out of your body very quickly. Holding your breath won't help you with anything, in fact it will only make things worse.
Amount of time of useful consciousness decrease per altitude and most airlines cruise at 30,000 up to 44,000 MSL:
FL250 (25,000 ft; 7,600 m) 3 to 6 minutes
FL280 (28,000 ft; 8,550 m) 2.5 to 3 minutes
FL300 (30,000 ft; 9,150 m) 1 to 3 minutes
FL350 (35,000 ft; 10,650 m) 30 secs to 1 minute
FL400 (40,000 ft; 12,200 m) 15 to 20 seconds
FL430 (43,000 ft; 13,100 m) 9 to 15 seconds
FL500 (50,000 ft; 15,250 m) 6 to 9 seconds

You literally have seconds in many cases.

Rapid decompression event, don't try to hold your breath or inhale when you hear the boom; either can tear your lungs, and can result in death. You likely will feel a sucking sensation, allow that to correspond with an exhalation. Once you fully exhaled, begin breathing as normal, and don O2 asap.

I don't know if anyone else looked for this, but Susan put Destin's mask back up/on; and it looked like he turned the regulator supply on right after that. It moved between shots initially, and at 08:31 (the second display of the scene), he reaches for the switch. This is of interest to me because the mask alone doesn't do much without the oxygen supply, and it wasn't given much focus in the video beyond Randy in the control room saying "get all 3 switches up". Erland Johansen in the comments made a point of pulling on the mask hose in airliners to start air flow for this reason. There's also a difference between being able to do something and being able to decide to do it. AFTER the mask's on, it seems he realized what was happening and bumped the supply switch before Susan checked it (or the supply switch getting turned on didn't make it in the video).

Also, is "angle of bank" a joke term for expelled human gasses in that training center? That doesn't look like a motion simulator.

at 8:20 he's smiling when he says i don't want to die but the second after that his facial expression completely changes and at 8:26 you can see he realizes the helplessness and depravity of his situation, i know those feels all to well.... when i was in college some friends and i went down to the rec center all the time and practiced and experimented with holding our breath underwater for long periods of time, well one day i pushed myself a little too far and i'm sitting at the bottom of the pool in 13 feet of water, my watch telling me i've been down there for over 4 minutes, my brain is screaming at me that i needed air but i felt like i was on a cloud, light as a feather, like Dustin said those good feeling tingles, i attempted to swim to the surface but you just cannot function at that point you are too far gone, i couldn't move, it would have been the most peaceful death ever... i was playing football at the time and it took 3 of my friends to pull my limp 6'3" 230 lb frame out of the water, they said when they got down to me my face was as purple as a plumb from my body pushing ever ounce of blood to my brain trying to feed it oxygen..... good times and good memories

A good illustration of why a trained pilot MUST know his personal early signs of hypoxia and immediately respond by dropping altitude and/or going to the alternate O2 supply.

Destin here was in a near-useless, close to unconscious (but still conscious) state I used to see a lot in divers when they had nitrogen narcosis (aka "depth drunk" or getting "narced"). Getting narced is really just Boyle's Law going in the exact opposite direction as 20% O2 that's pressurized too low; once the 78% nitrogen in breathing air gets pressurized too HIGH, it starts acting on your nervous system like it was nitrous oxide at the dentist: a common description is "1 martini per 50 feet of depth on air". Same way you can easily die from too many martinis, you can die from nitrogen narcosis, especially since severe intoxication at hundreds feet under the sea is not exactly conducive to safe decision-making. Depending on how skilled you are, some guys can work through a mild degree of narc, but once you go too far, there's no going back. A badly narced diver will ignore commands, shake off their dive partner, ignore their dive computer, and often go DEEPER instead of going up... they're too intoxicated to act logically to save themselves, even though on some level they know they're dying.

Okay, I need to preface this by saying it really is a serious question despite the subject matter. If it's already been addressed somewhere else in the comments, sorry, I couldn't find it. Anyway, at 3:42 or so, the control booth guy says that they're "going to give you a little bit of a vent to get rid of some of that angle of bank you guys were talking about." What did that phrase mean? I'm pretty sure that room wasn't actually banking, unless it was on hydraulic legs or something that weren't visible, and why would a "vent" help that anyway? Unless you edited out a big chunk of video just before that, the thing "you guys were talking about" was that everyone was farting from the dropping pressure. Which makes it sound as though he's saying that they're going to vent the chamber a bit to get rid of some of the, uh, more noxious gases before you had to take your masks off. That would make "angle of bank" some obscure astronaut euphemism for breaking wind. Is it? I mean, as well as the normal meaning of the phrase. Sorry so long, but I'm thinking if I just wrote, "Hey when he says 'angle of bank' does he mean farts?" no one would think I was serious. Hey Destin, I was checking that chart about altitudes. So you are saying at 40 000 feet, you got around 10 seconds of consciousness. How is that possible while I can hold my breath for a minute easily? I am a jiu jitsu practitioner, and the 10 seconds almost looks like a blood choke (constriction of the carotid arteries to cut the blood supply to the brain, making your opponent pass out literally in seconds). Similarly to the Hypoxia test you did, when you release the choke, the brains gets its access to oxygen again, and the guy wakes up within a few seconds.

So I was wondering how 10 seconds is possible while the blood keeps going to the brain? I just did a quick test while typing this. I emptied my lungs completely and then started a timer. Turns out I can avoid breathing for 25 seconds quite easily on empty lungs. could probably go 30 or 35 seconds if I had been willing to suffer a bit more lol. So how is 10 seconds possible? do you loose oxygen through your skin in a depressurized environment? That or simply the stress of the situation that could make you waste a ton of energy and use your oxygen reserves very fast (which is another phenomenon beginner Jiu Jitsu practitioners experience lol)

Thanks! :)

When you're​ experiencing lack of oxygen, your body wants to keep the vital parts of you up and running. Like heart, lungs and brain.
But brain uses a lot of energy, upto 20% (of what entire body is using) while simple problem solving excercise.

That is the reason your brain stops spending oxygen on problem solving, and strives to keep you alive. ✌
Good job brain!

Mr. Dustin, what is the main difference between hypoxia and carbon monoxide poisoning.

"Flight level" and "Altitude" are not exactly the same thing. Altitude is a number of feet above sea level using a barometer like interment called an altimeter which it set to the barometric pressure as measured at a weather station.
Flight level is used for higher elevations (usually above 17000 feet MSL) where accuracy is not so critical.The pilot sets in a standard altimeter setting and flies that altitude.
So long as everyone in a given airspace uses the same system vertical clearance can be maintained.

I went through this training at Peterson AFB just two weeks ago and I couldn't agree with this video more! I felt a lot of symptoms of hypoxia and I could not last nearly as long as Destin. I felt tingling in my hands and feet, blurred vision, confusion
(I couldn't even do simple math problems), and air hunger. While I was inhaling and exhaling faster and faster due to the air hunger, I felt totally fine as if I wasn't having any issues. I thought feeling air hunger would compare to gasping for air when drowning. Truly a great learning experience, especially since my job is inspect and repair these types of equipment that pilots use daily.

Some airplane crashes are sometimes due to hypoxia. I watched a documentary about one. When issues on the plane showed up, the pilots had to go to their emergency guide on what to do. The investigators noticed something when they were simulating what happened to the pilots. The guide's first step did not tell them to put on the mask first, instead it said to do some lengthy checkups THEN put on masks. By the time they got to step 2 on the guide, hypoxia has set in fully and they were gone.


The Plane became a rogue plane and was just flying until it ran out of fuel or hit something. One of the jets that was sent in to investigate noticed the cockpit's windows were all frozen or fogged up.

After the investigations conclusion they had to revise the guide and made putting on the mask as the first step.

It's really crazy that it happens that quickly, and it makes me wonder about all sorts of decay rate questions:

How much pressure could you keep in your lungs if you held your breath just before your air stopped?

What would happen to your blood if you hyperventilated before going to low pressure, and if nothing horrible happens (like the bends), how long would the hemoglobin held oxygen extend your functional time?

Does the pressure also change arterial blood flow?

This problem is fascinating because the models governing blood oxygenation and brain function are so chaotic. Try holding your breath with and without prior hyperventilation and you will get drastically differing times (1 minute versus 3-4), same with your body in and out of cold water, not to mention levels of personal fitness.

"there is way less oxygen up there" - The amount of oxygen changes very little with altitude in the lower regions of the atmosphere. There is almost as much oxygen at FL350 as it is at FL250 as it is in FL100, but it is the partial pressure (which is the force pushing O2 into your hemoglobin) that is severely reduced at higher alts. and makes us get hypoxia.

Thanks for another very interesting video, and tremendously emotional one at the same time. I have a couple of questions/comments though.

Firstly I would like to point out that I in no way want to question the severity of the message of Your video, and becoming unconscious certainly is something You would want to avoid.
That being said I personally highly doubt that You would have died or even taken any "serious damage" if You had fallen unconscious.
And I simply ground my assumption on the "Extremely well controlled environment" You were in at the time of the "self inflicted emergency".
You most certainly would have been put under oxygen, and given assisted respiration and resuscitation had that been necessary. And given that You were "simply oxygen depleted" and You are a "healthy Young specimen" I believe that a "full recovery" would be the norm (of course there are always the outliers, so it's never without risk) .

Secondly, as far as I understand it You have no recollection of the event where You were "on the brink", and my guess is that it will come back to You possibly "dimly" and somewhat fragmented but still. And my grounds for saying this is that I myself was rescued from drowning in a diving incident. And for a period after the event my memories of the 30 last seconds before blackout were absolutely blank. How ever as time passed my memories started to come back, although not "in full" and as "clear" as if I had been fully alert at the "event", after all I was more or less unCONCIOUS as my brain registered them.

Again thanks for another fantastic video.
Best regards MR

TO ALL THE PEOPLE THINKING "Oh, well why can't I just hold my breath?"
The facets:
Outside = (reaaaally) Low pressure
Your lungs = Normal pressure
Pressurized air in soft formed containers expands

Did you see the gloves?
Your lungs would explode (alveole would burst) if you made an effort to hold your breath. Killing you faster than hypoxia in a painful death

And the "Wouldn't beathing really fast help?"
Not really. The air is so thin that you most likely use more oxygen to move your diaphragm than you can inhale.

It was with the Air Force, they used rapid decompression at higher altitude, and their tests were the same child toy putting shapes in holes (though it was a ball container and the host held it himself), simple single digit subtraction, and identifying playing cards that were shown to them.

The host quickly deteriorated. He got the first shape and subtraction correct (slowly) but not the playing card (I think he was shown something like an 8 of spades but thought it was an Ace). The second round of tests were completely wrong (he slowly answered "4" to the question of 8 - 3).

The terrifying part was again when asked to put his oxygen back on. I'll never forget seeing a grown, intelligent, man holding a childs toy who, when told "Put your oxygen back on or you will die.", simply looked at the doctor the way an infant looks at a stranger. Unable to speak or comprehend what he was being told.

When you responded "I don't want to die." it felt like you were a toddler with basic speech rather than an infant unable to speak.

Fun fact too, the oxygen masks in airliners only have about 10 minutes worth of oxygen.  Not only this, but they don't even store oxygen in them.  They are chemical oxygen generators.  By pulling the mask, you pull a pin that starts the reaction between the chemicals, that is why they tell you to pull it all the way.  If you don't pull it far enough for the pin to release, no oxygen will actually flow into your mask.

As a freediver, one can learn how to deal (a bit) better with hypoxia.
I've experienced a few black outs / faints, from going under that ~56% SaO2 limit, and after some the in the video mentioned (subtle) symptoms it feels like you're quickly slipping into a dream. To me it does, but I'm sure to people who do not know the range of effects, they'll experience the terror of not knowing and loosing control. Under the 56% SaO2 the body faints, shuts down the whole body and major organs and 'prioritises' brain and heart. Those can keep functioning in this lower state for about 4-5 minutes before permanent damage start occurring. In cold water it may be longer. Still it's very important a fainted person gets help immediately. The sooner O2 gets into the person's bloodstream and brain, the shorter the recovery time is. Freedivers learn how and why in freediver courses. If you ever see a person faint in the pool make sure to bring them up, hold them up face above the water, clear the face and airways, give mouth to mouth. If you're quick the victem will come around quickly, often with some body spasms followed by surprise, bewilderment, anger as to why you're holding them up. They'll have no recollection as to what happened. Tell them to breath, relax, and then tell them what happened and help them to get out of the pool. In freediving competitions BO victems often get pure O2 for a few minutes to help speedy recovery. Under water faint victims must see a doctor to check for 'second drowning'. They need to take a day rest and drink, eat and sleep well, no breath-holds. A freediver cannot rescue himself from a BO. Most freedivers never felt a BO coming. Never freedive alone. Always have a observant, knowledgeable buddy close.

I also got to fly on the Vomit Comet back in 2009 in an RGSFOP experiment and also got to do the hypoxia training. For me, the tingling was the worst after 4 minutes, I had to put my mask back on. It felt like the pins and needles when an arm or leg badly falls asleep, except it was affecting my entire body. I remember my vision darkening and not being able to see color very well either almost immediately after losing air. Also, my fingernails turned a deep dark purple around 2 minutes in.

Man though, if you're an engineering student in college, try your best to get into NASA's RGSFOP program. Make a team and submit an experiment it's a once in a life time experience.

As he sat there with a smile on his face, he said "I don't ant to die." That is what it's like to be addicted to opiates... Although this may not have been his intention, he experienced what many heroin addicts have.

I've been in recovery for almost a year, and even after all this time, it still gives me anxiety to remember what it was like at my peak usage. I wanted to stop, and even though I knew that my tolerance had gotten to a point where the line between an overdose and a satisfying dose was paper thin, I still wasn't able to stop without either another human intervening with Naloxone to revive me from an overdose, or without using Suboxone to prevent cravings and mitigate the effects of withdrawal.

Excellent! Excellent stuff! I've done the chamber twice (once with the FAA and once with the Air Force -- AF is the better experience, BTW) and learned so much each time. Funny (or not) thing is, I bet Destin doesn't even remember saying the words, "I don't wanna die." Around that point, your brain isn't engaged in memory-making any more - it's concentrating on keeping life-functions running: heart, lungs, etc. I've done the toy exercise and others. Even counting becomes a challenge. Simple math problems while hypoxic? Forget about it. (Pun intended.) Your own handwriting becomes illegible too! Back on oxygen, everything returns to normal almost instantly! (Be careful of hyperventilation - personal experience...)

This is the most frightening video I have watched on your channel. I have severe obstructive sleep apnea. Without a biPAP, my AHI is 70 (normal is less than 4). Basically, that means I stop breathing for longer than 10 seconds an average of 70 times per hour. During my first sleep study, I had 300 apneas and my blood oxygen level dropped to 72% over the course of 4 hours.

Getting married saved my life. My wife didn't sleep the first few months of our marriage due to me snoring/gasping for air. This led to visiting an ENT who referred me to a sleep specialist. I also had other symptoms like daytime drowsiness, dizziness, numbness/tingling in my extremities, and general confusion when waking up. I generally felt like I was paralyzed when first waking up. Perhaps the worst symptom was night terrors. It was basically my brain forcing me to wake up because I was dying.

After a year of treatment I feel like a new man. I wake up feeling refreshed, and I'm able to concentrate better at work. I've also lost 30 lbs (I was slightly overweight before), and my blood pressure has started to return to normal. OSA normally affects people who are very overweight, but it was genetic in my case.

I was amazing to see the effect of hypoxia on someone while they are conscious. At the same time, I can't believe I was unknowingly subjecting my body to this every night for probably a few years. Thanks for this video!

I see many people have never experienced Anemia before. Standing up real quick and then getting confused, loosing vision, motor control, speech, and possibly consciousness because that's basically the same effects. Thankfully I'm like Destin and experience Euphoria and Tingling when it happens, so it's not too unpleasant most of the time. But I can attest to the fact you aren't going to be able to help yourself or anyone else in that position, thankfully sudden Anemia from Iron Deficiency passes quickly without intervention.

However it's happened a few times at inopportune times, like standing up real quick and doing a pull-up on a pull up bar before realizing I was about to black out, then waking up some time later (probably just a few seconds) laying on the ground with my head inches away from the corner of a metal object which would have likely done serious damage if I had hit my head on it (also was alone at the time).

Thanks for the video Destin, very awesome! I found it interesting the difference in how you can simulate high altitude environments. You used a Hypobaric Chamber to change the partial pressure of the atmosphere because the percent of Oxogen in the atmosphere never changes just the amount of it due to the loss of pressure. I am a student at Embry Riddle Aeronautical University, and here we use a Normabaric chamber to simulate high altitudes up to FL300. The Normabaric chamber uses machines called Oxogen scrubbers that reduces the amount of Oxogen in a closed environment without having to change the pressure. This makes it less expensive and safer since there is no change in atmospheric pressure, there is no danger of ear or sinus blocks, trapped gas, or decompression sickness. Enjoyed the video, and getting Smarter Every Day!

Would like to point out here that in case of a decompression at that altitude pilots will perform an emergency descent. That takes about 30 seconds. You might be unconscious by then, but the brain can handle up to about 4 minutes of zero oxygen (no pulse, basically) before you start to get brain damage, so to be perfectly honest the oxygen masks in airplanes are pretty much gimmicks, they are there to make you feel safe, but the don't really make a difference in whether you live or die. The pilots, however, obviously have to have killer reflexes when it comes to getting their masks on in case of an explosive decompression. They also have proper oxygen tanks with proper regulators as opposed to the chemical oxygen reactors (basically a can with two chemicals that release oxygen (and lots of heat, actually) when combined (you combine them when you yank the masks down from their elevated position)) used for the passengers. Pilots tank provides oxygen for probably in excess of an hour, while the passengers reactors only run for a few minutes before they run out. It's just for show, just a gimmick to make people feel safe.
"But what happens if they can't descend right away" you ask. Well, on the rare occasion that there is for example a Mount Everest or similar obstacle underneath, that's actually where the masks might make a difference. However, bare in mind that you usually hurl along at 8-900 km/h, so any such obstacle will have passed really quickly, and that airplanes actually have the ability to turn.

Destin, you do a great job, but I have to call out one thing you said. Hopefully this will help your understanding of altitude induced hypoxia.

Our entire atmosphere from the surface to 100 km up consists of the same percentage of the main elements - O2, N2, Argon, etc... So you do not have any "less" oxygen at 25,000 ft than you do at sea level. What is different is the partial pressure of oxygen.

Consider when you are at the bottom of the pool. You have the pressure of the column of water above you due to the Earth's gravitational force of the water. Air can and does often acts like a fluid... as it does for this example. Consider that at sea level you have 100 km of air in a column above you. This "pressure" helps to "force" oxygen into our lungs.

Consider pressurized aircraft which can fly in the high altitudes. These aircraft do not have any oxygen bottles or oxygen generators for their flights (only for emergencies). The cabins are pressurized to increase to make the partial pressure of oxygen breathable, by increasing the pressure... they aren't adding "air / oxygen" to the cabin. Likewise you experienced the opposite when they lowered the pressure in the atmospheric chamber to experience a lower partial pressure of oxygen in your lungs. Aircraft pull air from the outside, pressurizing it, and then sending it to the cabin. At the same time there is an outflow valve which lets out air and also helps to regulate the pressure in the cabin. Typical cabin pressures are set to a similar pressure you'd experience at 8000 ft above the ground. The oxygen carried aboard these aircraft is for when the pressurization systems fail and they can no longer maintain that partial pressure.

Once I had to fast for 12 hours before a blood test, but I ate too little and drank too little water and fainted. Before I fainted I was able to notify the doctor, after which I experienced dizziness, tunnel vision and what felt like all of my thoughts were blocked out by static. All I could hear was static. I think I may have had slight pins-and-needles but I don't quite remember. My last conscious memory was of one nurse and myself being in the room, next thing I know, there's like 5 people round me and they're wheeling in an oxygen machine. I used to be a flight attendant and I'm so happy to see that you gave a very real demonstration about how dangerous hypoxia is.

Of note, explosive decompression, or total loss of cabin pressure within one second, does leave you with 10 to 30 seconds of useful consciousness, but if that were to occur, the captain would immediately lower the altitude of the plane as fast as they can safely accomplish it. If you were to pass out from explosive decompression your brain won't be oxygen starved for long, because you'll be at a reasonable altitude within a minute.

Also, the oxygen canisters only provide about 5 minutes worth of oxygen, even though it will take longer than that to safely land the plane.
